dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A METAL SIGN on a chainlink fence being whipped by a nast storm: "ARROWHEAD PROJECT -- MILITARY PERSONNEL ONLY." WE CLOSE IN as LIGHTNING BOOMS AND CRASHES, moving past the to reveal a low, nondescript building...

dialogues.speaker: INT. ARROWHEAD PROJECT LAB -' NIGHT
dialogues.text: .--in which high-tech EQUIPMENT encircles a huge, pressur CHAMBER. The chamber is low-tech -- massively thick glass windows, ribbed-and-riveted steel, like an old-fashioned helmet reinterpreted as a large room. It's dark inside, fathomless. Lab-coated PERSONNEL are everywhere, seated a work stations, computer screens streaming data. A pair of tense scientists, MACHEN and NAYLOR, hover at t shoulder of a seated tech named PHILLIPS.

dialogues.speaker: NAYLOR
dialogues.text: We should pull the plug for tonight. The storm...

dialogues.speaker: MACHEN
dialogues.text: ++-S'got nothing to do with it. our Power sources are shielded. Stable. (off Naylor's look) Relax. Activity mounts. We hear a rising TURBINE WHINE. Banks of VIDEO AND WAVE-SPECTRUM CAMERAS are trained at the darkne within the chamber. Everybody's intensely focused, eyeing their data streams, murmuring to one another, the whole v very "Mission Control." Phillips glances up:

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIPS
dialogues.text: Sir? Alignments are set.

dialogues.speaker: MACHEN
dialogues.text: Engage. Switches are thrown, commands keyed in. Scient peer into the chamber, eyes straining into the

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE CHAMBER
dialogues.text: ists and soldiers darkness, and: A_FAINT PINPOINT OF LIGHT appears inside the chamber, blo nto existence from nothing, growing ever brighter like a spotlight being shined through a keyhole...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hush falls. Faces are slack, stunned. A UNIFORMED COLON moves to Machen's side, gazing in wonder as: Inside the chamber, the "keyhole" widens, irising open to become a portal of dancing, swirling light. It shimmers, growing larger and brighter, halating the glass... People are struck with wonder, light rippling their faces reluctantly tearing their eyes away to check their boards

dialogues.speaker: MACHEN
dialogues.text: Check your data streams. Give me constant updates, flag any anomalies... Suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIGHTNING slams from the sky, blasting along the fence, t power lines, anything metal or electrical. A SOLDIER is b out of the guard booth as the surge EXPLODES every circui and panel, sending up showers of sparks as it courses alo ---and WE PAN the surge as it goes blazing into the TURBI powering the lab, sending them into smoking overdrive...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +--and creating instant panic as:

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIPS
dialogues.text: We got a hell of a surge! Needles are way in the red!

dialogues.speaker: MACHEN
dialogues.text: Disengage! Shut it down! A mad flurry as they try to shut the system down -- but t WHINE CONTINUES TO BUILD, the "portal of light" within th chamber growing larger and brighter still...

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: C'mon, kill the goddamn power!

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIPS
dialogues.text: I can't!

dialogues.speaker: MACHEN
dialogues.text: What do you mean, you can't? Trip the breakers! Machen darts over, frantically punching buttons. Phillips screen is flashing data almost too fast to make sense of, while the light inside the chamber swirls ever faster...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The system's overloading!

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIPS
dialogues.text: Where's the power coming from?

dialogues.speaker: MACHEN
dialogues.text: {gazes up, realizing) The lightning. We're pulling it right out of the sky. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right -- overlapping BOLTS OF LIGHTNING are blazing coursing through the array of power turbines...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .-While the light within the chamber builds into a whirlw of unearthly power. People shield their eyes from the gla helpless to do anything but watch. A few techs break and

dialogues.speaker: MACHEN
dialogues.text: Remain at your stations!

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: How thick is that goddamn glass?

dialogues.speaker: MACHEN
dialogues.text: Thick enough. Pressurized to forty atmospheres. But even Machen sounds uncertain. The Colonel moves close peering deeper into the light. It's blinding us, but:

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (hushed) Am I...seeing something in there? ANGLE SHIFTS TO VIDEO TECH #1, scared shitless, trying to darken and adjust the image enough to see.

dialogues.speaker: VIDEO TECH
dialogues.text: There's something...

dialogues.speaker: MACHEN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: VIDEO TECH
dialogues.text: +--Something. ..moving. We see it. Something in the light. Something...slithery. that's when the first CRACK appears in the glass. The SOU OF THE SNAP makes everybody freeze, staring in horror, desperately hoping it holds, but:  4. CRACK, SNAP! Another crack. The glass begins to spiderweb People turn and run, but it's too late, because:

dialogues.speaker: MACHEN
dialogues.text: (softly) Jesus. WHAM -- the first window EXPLODES out, lacerating a tech flying glass, blowing him back in his seat as a HUGE ERUP OF OTHERWORLDLY MIST blows through and engulfs him... ---and the windows EXPLODE in sequence as the mist freigh trains into the room, blowing techs back in their chairs, engulfing people on the run, muffling their screams, wipi everything completely and utterly into: BLACKNESS. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: FADE TO
dialogues.text: FLASHES OF SLO-MO LIGHTNING play ghostlike and surreal, r the faces of a family breathlessly watching the storm app DAVID DRAYTON, his wife STEFF, their 5 year-old son BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're silhouetted at a big picture window, storm roilin SLO-MO outside, clouds rippling, LIGHTNING arcing across sky. There's a huge old TREE out there, whipping in-the w David turns, murmurs something to Steff -- we can’t hear words, just the HOWLING OF THE WIND.

dialogues.speaker: A MATCH
dialogues.text: flares in the dark, touches a candle wick. The flame rise bringing light...

dialogues.speaker: BASEMENT STAIRS
dialogues.text: ;-and they come down the steps, each carrying a candle, B leading the way. The boy is especially careful carrying h candle, back straight, being brave. The candlelight weaves and dances, making the shadows mov sinister ways. The family passes by us, gliding down the and disappearing from view, the meager glow of their cand diminishing to blackness again...

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: +++as we SLOWLY PUSH IN on a finished PAINTING on an ease storm thundering outside the picture window b.g. The pain is art for a movie poster, and exquisitely done. WHAM! The painting gets smashed as a BLAST OF LIGHTNING A THUNDER sends that huge old tree CRASHING straight at us  >. through the picture window where the family stood only mo ago, freight-training into the room in a rain-driven expl of glass and smoking tree trunk, as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gorgeous -- blue skies, high clouds, birds twitterin The house is at the edge of a wide lake, mountains b.g. B runs out of the house in his pajamas, pauses at the oak t was split in half by lightning.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Wow! He goes charging off. David exits the house with the dama painting in his hands, checking it in daylight. Debris is everywhere -- branches, lawn furniture, other trees downe

dialogues.speaker: DAVID,
dialogues.text: stops before the charred tree trunk, scowling at the part that went through the house. Steff exits onto the porch.

dialogues.speaker: STEFF
dialogues.text: Power's still out. Food's gonna go bad.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Do a list. I'll head into town before the store gets bought out.

dialogues.speaker: STEFF
dialogues.text: {re: the painting) Can you save it?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: This? No way. I'll have to do it again from scratch. I'll have to call the studio, see if they'll extend my deadline.

dialogues.speaker: STEFF
dialogues.text: What choice do they have?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You kidding? They can whip up some bad Photoshop poster in an afternoon. Two big heads. They do it all the- time. (gazes at the painting) I should'a brought it downstairs last night. Stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You couldn't know a tree was going to come through the window.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (looks to the window) I'll hit the hardware store too. Get some plastic sheeting, duct tape. I'll seal that up before dark, order some new glass in.

dialogues.speaker: STEFF
dialogues.text: (beat, realizing) That was your grandfather's tree. The one he planted...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah. I used to play in it. She comes down the steps, takes him in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Just stuff, hon. We're all right, that's what counts. We were standing at that window. If we hadn't gone downstairs when we did... The rest is left unsaid. She shudders. Suddenly, Billy co skidding around the corner of the house, amped up:

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Mom! Dad! Ya gotta come see!

dialogues.speaker: STEFF
dialogues.text: Billy, take it easy! Don't go charging around!

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: But ya gotta come lookit! The boathouse is all bashed! There's a dock on the rocks--and, and--there's trees in the cove! Holy crap!

dialogues.speaker: STEFF
dialogues.text: Billy!

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Sorry, Ma--but you gotta--wow! He's gone again, charging from view.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Having spoken, the doomsayer departs. Steff can't help laughing in spite of everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you two always manage to make me laugh?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You have low standards? (smiles, takes her hand) Let's go see the damage.

dialogues.speaker: STEFF
dialogues.text: I can do that in my living room.” They proceed around the corner of the house ---and pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: reveals their boathouse smashed flat by a huge pine from neighbor's property -- the wind snapped it off near the b and over it went, bam. Steff looks pissed:

dialogues.speaker: STEFF
dialogues.text: That's Norton's tree.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah. The dead one I've been asking him to take down for three years before it blew over. That tree. They come down toward the water, where Billy's peering wi bright-eyed excitement at the boathouse:

dialogues.speaker: _ BILLY
dialogues.text: Wow, it really got smooshed!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (mutters to Steff) Nobody appreciates good destruction like a five year-old. Billy glances up, seeing something across the lake.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Wooaaah... David and Steff look up, and now they see it too: The far end of the lake is gone. In its place is a wall o mist, unnaturally straight and creeping this way. It has deeply strange quality to it -- instead of refracting sun as normal mist would, this glows dead-white.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: What is it, Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Fog bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the lake?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: We've had fog on the lake before.

dialogues.speaker: STEFF
dialogues.text: Not like that.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Probably a leftover from the storm. Two fronts meeting, something like that.

dialogues.speaker: STEFF
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Honey, I'm not the weatherman.

dialogues.speaker: STEFF
dialogues.text: C'mon, Billy, inside. Daddy's heading into town, if you wanna go. (to David) You coming?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm gonna go have a chat with our neighbor about his tree. (off her look) Don't worry, I'm not gonna punch bim in the nose or anything.

dialogues.speaker: STEFF
dialogues.text: David, what's the point? You know what he's gonna say, don't you? "Sue me." Maybe we should.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Honey, one property dispute with this guy was enough to last me a lifetime. I'm just gonna ask for -his insurance info, that's all. She heads for the house, taking Billy. CAMERA FOLLOWS Dav as he makes his way to the edge of the yard, steps over a fence, and proceeds onto his neighbor's property. He starts hearing a low sound ahead as he walks -- whut-w whut! Somebody trying to start a chainsaw.

dialogues.speaker: NORTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Shit. David keeps moving toward the sound -- whut-whut-whut!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Motherfuck. He proceeds up the slope of the yard -- whut-whut-whut!

dialogues.speaker: NORTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Cocksucker. And then we see him: BRENT NORTON, the neighbor, an overw New York City lawyer in his 50's. He's bent over a chains face pinched with sheer frustration as he yanks the cord and again to no avail -- whut-whut-whut! Whut-whut-whut! Norton suddenly realizes he's not alone -- he turns, seei David. A beat, both of them embarrassed, then:

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Won't start?

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: Goddamn thing cost two hundred dollars, why should it start?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I guess you've seen the boathouse.

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: (bristling) Yeah? So?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Nothing. I just think we should swap insurance info. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: (bitter laugh) Oh, my agent's gonna love me... David follows Norton's glance, sees it: a car can be glim under the branches of a tree that came down and crushed i

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (slowly realizing) Oh. Oh shit. That's not the Benz, is it? The 1960?

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: I drove it up this trip. I was gonna bring the station wagon, but...the weather was so nice when I left New York...you know, top down...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, man, Brent, I'm sorry. Sincerely.

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: That's nice of you to say.  10.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No, I mean it. That car was cherry. I hate seeing it like that. Norton absorbs this, nods.

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: I'll find my insurance guy's number, bring it by later. That okay?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No problem. David walks away. Norton's watching him go. Norton hesita hating to ask, but:

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: David? (David turns back) You're not heading into town today by any chance, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steff£'s at the sink with the water running, separating b and unbroken dishes. She glances out the window, surprise see Norton trailing David into the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steff exits onto the porch.

dialogues.speaker: STEFF
dialogues.text: Brent.

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: Hi, Steff. (awkward beat) Some morning, huh?

dialogues.speaker: STEFF
dialogues.text: You could say that.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Brent needs a new chainsaw. He's gonna ride into town with us.

dialogues.speaker: STEFF
dialogues.text: Something wrong with your car?

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: A tree came down on it.

dialogues.speaker: STEFF
dialogues.text: (beat) I was sorry to hear about Carla, Brent. We all were.  dle

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: Thank you. It was...sudden. Two months from when she was diagnosed.

dialogues.speaker: STEFF
dialogues.text: I'm sure that wasn't easy.

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: No. It wasn't. Billy comes charging out of the house in fresh jeans and sneakers, past Steff, down the stairs:

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Ready, Daddy! DAVID ; Great, champ! Mr. Norton's coming too.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (suddenly shy) Hi, Mr. Norton.

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: Biya, Billy.

dialogues.speaker: STEFF
dialogues.text: (coming down the steps) Here's the grocery list...pick up some ice, too, if they've got it, so we can keep the milk cold...

dialogues.speaker: NORTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That is the weirdest thing. They turn. Norton's shading his eyes, gazing across the l The mist has swallowed half of it, still coming this way.

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: That mist. I saw it coming down the mountain this morning, now it's halfway across the lake. Some kind of inversion layer, I guess. David stares at it, getting a bad feeling. Something abou that mist spooks him, but he has no idea why.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hon? Why don’t you come with us?

dialogues.speaker: STEFF
dialogues.text: i'm up to my ears in glass and mud, that's why. It'll take me all day. You guys go, I'll be fine.  12. She kisses him, heads back inside...

Steff emerges from the house wearing a big floppy sun hat dragging a trash bag. She sees them, waves. David waves b puts his misgivings aside, drives out onto the rural road

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. SCOUT/RURAL ROAD
dialogues.text: ..-where a PAIR OF ORANGE CMP (municipal power) TRUCKS co lumbering by us, going the other way. ANGLE TO David at t wheel of the Scout, Norton in the passenger seat, Billy i back. David glances in the rearview at the trucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, CMP's out in force. Maybe we'll get our power back.

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: We can hope. A stretch of awkward silence, both men feeling uncomforta riding together. Norton reaches for the radio.

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: You mind? David shrugs -- go ahead. Norton starts scanning for a st

dialogues.text: That was some storm, huh?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: One for the books. For a moment there last night, I thought we were gonna take off and head for 02.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Like Dorothy!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (smiles) Yeah, champ, like Dorothy.

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: WOXO's off the air. Just static. (keeps scanning) Portland's still broadcasting. That easy listening station...  13s.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Daddy, look! Army men! David glances up as MILITARY TRUCKS AND VEHICLES race by the opposite direction, just like the CMP trucks did.

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: It's those guys from the Arrowhead Project. (looks to David) You're a local. Any idea what they do up there?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm sure you've heard all the crazy stories.

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: The gal at the dry cleaners swears they've got a crashed flying saucer up there. Frozen alien bodies.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID _
dialogues.text: Edna, right. Miss Tabloid. "I Had Bigfoot's Baby." "Satan's Face Appears in Oilwell Fire.* All that good hard news. (beat) You know Mrs. Carmody? Owns that weird antique shop in town? .

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: The creepy place with all the dead stuffed animals in the window?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That's the one. Bumped into her at the gas station one day and she starts in on Arrowhead. She informs us they're fooling around with "atomic things." That's what she said: "Those Army boys are shooting atoms into the air, make no mistake."

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: What'd you say?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Not me, my son. My five year-old. (in rearview mirror) What'd you say, Billy?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I told her the air's full of atoms. That's what our teacher says. Everything's full of atoms.  14.

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: How'd that go over?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Mrs. Carmody looks at Billy and says: "These are different atoms, son. Secret atoms." Then she goes on a rant about God's punishment coming down on us. You don't mess with God's atoms, apparently. Suddenly, another stream of ARMY VEHICLES goes whizzing b

dialogues.text: They're in a big hurry.

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: Maybe their power's out too. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -.-.and a BEARDED BIKER ON A HARLEY pops into frame and c them off, startling everybody as David slams the brakes.

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: Jesus! Stupid shit... The biker pulls ahead, rumbling toward the market. David resumes cruising for a spot. Billy points:

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Daddy! Somebody's leaving!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pull in, a lucky spot close to the to get a call through on his cell phone the Scout, gives Norton a look. market. David's trying as they get out of

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: No signal?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Why don't you get started? I'11 use the payphone, give Steff a call.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Can I go with Mr. Norton, Daddy?  15. Norton's a bit thrown by this. David hesitates, hands the list to Billy.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Make sure you hold his hand when you cross. Billy takes Norton's hand and looks both ways, crossing t traffic aisle to the market. Norton looks a bit flustered but goes with it. Billy turns, calls back to David:

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Ask Mommy if she wants a Spiderman comic book! I bet she does!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You think? - Billy nods. David smiles, watches them enter the store. He goes to the payphone in front of the pharmacy, lifts t receiver...and gets a "circuit busy" signal: wah-wah-wah- He clicks the cradle a few times, puts the receiver back a sigh, heads toward:

dialogues.speaker: THE MARKET
dialogues.text: He almost bumps face-first into the automatic door -- he back, realizing the power's out. He pushes it open manual

dialogues.text: ..-and enters to find the store more crowded than he's ev seen it -- people clogging the aisles, long lines snaking the checkout counters. The cashiers are harried, totaling purchases by hand -- the registers are down. BUD BROWN (store manager) and OLLIE WEEKS (assistant mana are clipping receipts to the customers’ checks or cash, t them in a box. Both men are also bagging, helping out NOR THE BAG BOY, a skinny 18 year-old with stringy blond hair SALLY, a pretty teenage cashier, glances up and sees Davi entering.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Hey, Mr. Drayton...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Sally...you guys look jammed up.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Half the staff didn't show, plus the power's out.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Thought you had a generator.  16.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Only for emergency lights and to keep the food cold. Everything else, welcome to the Dark Ages. Bring your checkbook.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (smiles, moving on) Hey, Steff and I want a date night Thursday. You free to babysit Billy?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Heck yeah. I'm there. David moves to Ollie (wearing a bow tie), who's happy to a friendly face.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Crappy day, huh?

dialogues.speaker: OLLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, man, everybody's pissed off this morning. (his gaze shifts) Oh, great. And now it's complete. David turns, sees MRS. CARMODY enter. She seems like a ni (though eccentric) lady at first, but...well, we'll get t know her soon enough. She's in a canary-yellow pantsuit, annoyed to see such a long wait at the checkstands. On she goes,

dialogues.speaker: OLLIE
dialogues.text: What do you wanna bet she finds Satan lurking in the cantaloupes? {as she draws near) Good morning, Mrs. Carmody...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CARMODY
dialogues.text: With these lines? I wouldn't say there's much good about it, but I guess we'll have to make do. moving down the aisles.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (grins) Keep your head down, pal.

dialogues.speaker: OLLIE
dialogues.text: You know it. David moves on... WE FADE TO BLACK and bring up a TITLE CARD:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David finds Norton and Billy in an aisle, items already i the shopping cart, Norton puzzling over Steff's list.

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: Your wife should have been a doctor, : David. She could make a fortune in Manhattan with this handwriting. !

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I know, takes some getting used to. (takes the list) Why don't you get your stuff? We'll : meet you at the checkout.

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: Done. Norton grabs a hand-basket from the cart, starts away. He pauses, looks back. ;

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: David. Thanks for helping me today. David nods. Norton turns the corner, gone.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Are you and Mr. Norton gonna be friends now, Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I dunno, champ. "Friends" might be stretching it. We'll see. He grabs some items off the shelf, tosses them to Billy, relays them into the cart.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: But I guess you're not mad at each other any more.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I guess not. That's a start. They proceed down the aisle...

dialogues.speaker: OLLIE

dialogues.text: Got those windows taped up. Perhaps it'll do some good. David and Ollie trade a look -- they can’t believe that, don't want to be discouraging either. Amanda is the only who catches it. She draws closer:

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: That bad? David just give her a subtle nod -- yeah, that bad.

dialogues.text: Prepare to meet shit! Woman, your tongue must be hung in the middle so it can run on both ends! Myron's advancing on her, but Jim restrains him. ¢

dialogues.text: Come on, pal, easy now... People are pausing now, drawn to the confrontation, as:

dialogues.text: A LITTLE GIRL bursts into tears, buries her face against FATHER'S leg. The adults are either disgusted or fascinat but all are silent and listening now.

dialogues.text: You shut up that bad talk. Mrs. Carmody touches a hand to her mouth, finds a little there. It makes her smile...and she holds it up for all t see. Amanda backs away, realizing just how crazy she is.

dialogues.text: She had it coming! I'd have done it myself! Carmody singles Sally out, drifting ominously toward her.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CARMODY
dialogues.text: They'll get hold of you. Not today. Maybe tonight. When darkness comes. Sally shies back. Carmody turns slowly, addressing them a now, eyes going from face to face.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CARMODY
dialogues.text: They'll come at night, and take someone else. See if they don't. And when they do, when you're next, then you'll come weeping to me. You'll beg Mother Carmody to show you what to do.  DD.

dialogues.speaker: OLLIE
dialogues.text: That's fine, but until then, if you don't shut up, we'll wrap some of this tape around your mouth.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CARMODY
dialogues.text: You try it, Ollie Weeks. (turns to Amanda) And you, bitch. Hit me again if you dare. You'll be on your knees to me before it's through. She plants her Tootsie Pop back in her mouth, drifts quie off. People get out of her way. ANGLE FINDS one terrified WOMAN, pale and watching...already believing.

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING DAVID
dialogues.text: as the moment ends, everybody around him freaked-out and silent as they drift off to resume their preparations.

dialogues.speaker: OLLIE
dialogues.text: Those of you who aren't locals should know that Mrs. Carmody is well known in town for being unstable.

dialogues.speaker: BEARDED BIKER
dialogues.text: No shit. What was your first clue?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Okay, we can use the charcoal fluid and mops to make torches. And we got knives and such, God knows.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Which God, hers? He likes knives, apparently...

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: This may be a silly question, Bud, but you don't happen to have a gun . in the store?

dialogues.speaker: BUD
dialogues.text: Please. This isn't Dodge city. or Los Angeles. An old man, AMBROSE CORNELL, pipes up:

dialogues.speaker: AMBROSE
dialogues.text: Got a shotgun in my truck. I could try for it, if you want.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I don't think that's a good idea, Mr. Cornell.  56.

dialogues.speaker: AMBROSE
dialogues.text: I don’t either, son, but I thought I'd offer.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Well, I didn't think so...

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Hold on a minute. All eyes turn to her. She looks very self-conscious as sh opens her purse, digs around, and pulls out a small Smith Wesson J-frame revolver. i

dialogues.speaker: " AMANDA
dialogues.text: This gun...my husband's idea. : (embarrassed) i He insisted. He's away on business | a lot. It's not even loaded. :

dialogues.speaker: AMBROSB
dialogues.text: So what good is it? She goes into her purse again, brings out two plastic spe loaders, each containing six rounds.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You know how to use it?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA _
dialogues.text: I shot it only once, on a target range. Dan takes the gun, manages to fumble the cylinder open.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Okay, we got a gun. Who knows how to shoot it? Well, I mean. People glance around at each other. Then, reluctantly:

dialogues.speaker: OLLIB
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: BUD
dialogues.text: You? You'll be too damn drunk to see before dark.

dialogues.text: (ignoring him) I've done a lot of target shooting. I was state champion back in '94, David gives Ollie a look -- the little assistant manager full of surprises. dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Feeling better, champ?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Billy, I just don't know. I wish I did, but I don't.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (eyes brimming tears) I want her awful bad. I'm sorry about the times I was bad to her. David hugs him, pulls him close.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Mommy loves you, Billy. And I bet she's fine. I promise you I'm going to do everything I can to get us back to her, okay? That's all you have to think about. Billy nods, miserable. dialogues.text: Let us pass! Let us pass, please! David rises. Norton and his group (now on ly five people) appear with Joe dogging them, Mike joining in:

dialogues.text: We have, and we've made our decision. ‘ We're leaving.

dialogues.text: No. I will not.

dialogues.text: Take it up with the Devil when you Grop in on him. Chew it over at your leisure. She gives him a chilly smile. He just turns, exits.

dialogues.text: (softly) I saw it too.  DO. O£f Ollie's look, we go to:

dialogues.text: Wayne. Jesus. You scared the shit out of me.

dialogues.text: Sally--I'm sorry. Really. My bad. (hesitates) I...I saw you come in here. 1 thought. ..thought I'd come in and say hi. See how you're holding up.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Barely. How about you?

dialogues.text: Worried about my folks, I guess. You know they live up on Shoreham Road...less than five miles from here. This mist...who knows how far “it's spread... (pause) What about yours?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: They're out of town right now.

dialogues.speaker: JESSUP
dialogues.text: That's lucky. Means they're okay. Sally nods, trying to keep it together.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: How soon you shipping out?

dialogues.speaker: JESSUP
dialogues.text: Couple of weeks.  64.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: You scared about going over there?

dialogues.speaker: JESSUP
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sure I am. Their eyes meet. Pause. We feel the weight of things betw them that have been left unsaid for a long time.

dialogues.text: Wayne? How come you never asked me out? We flirted all through high school. I know you like me. So how come you never asked me out?

dialogues.speaker: JESSUP
dialogues.text: Dunno. I always wanted to. Stupid, I guess. She kisses him. It turns passionate. They start getting c away...but she stops, pushes him away...

dialogues.speaker: JESSUP
dialogues.text: (backs off) ++-shit, I’m sorry...

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: +--mo, don't be, it's just... (beat) Shit. I don’t want it to happen Tike this. Not in a shitty locker room at work. It's not exactly the way I always imagined it, y'know?

dialogues.speaker: JESSUP
dialogues.text: (nods, beat) Let’s just stay in here a while, then...okay? Just the two of us? She lays her head on his shoulder...

dialogues.text: --.and we find David's group sitting in an aisle: Billy, Amanda, Irene, Hattie. They're having a desultory meal of grilled chicken. Hattie's got Billy, clinging to him. dialogues.text: Hey, you gotta eat, big guy. Keep your strength up.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I'm not hungry.  65.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, maybe you'd bring me some more, huh? Go back there and get me some from Mr. Mackey, okay?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I'll go with you, Billy. Would that be okay?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: "kay. David gives Amanda a grateful look. She rises, takes Bill hand, heads toward the back. David looks to Hattie.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You gonna keep it together?

dialogues.speaker: HATTIE
dialogues.text: How bad will it be tonight?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hattie, I just don't know.

dialogues.speaker: HATTIE
dialogues.text: You let me keep Billy as much as you can. Okay? David, I'm...I think I'm in mortal terror. Yes, I believe that's what it is. But if I have Billy, I think I can be all right. I can be all right for him.

dialogues.speaker: IRENE
dialogues.text: We're all terrified, dear. There's no shame in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so worried about my Alan. The iast I saw him, he was out back mowing the yard. He's dead, I think. In my heart, I'm sure he's dead,

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You don't know any such thing.

dialogues.speaker: HATTIE
dialogues.text: What about Steff, David? Don't you have some feeling about...about whether she’s all right?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It's killing me not knowing. That's why I'm gonna keep it together and not give up hope. So I can get us back to her, me and my boy. That's all that matters.  66. Suddenly, Ollie's there, beer in hand, crouching down:

dialogues.speaker: OLLIE

dialogues.speaker: DAVID

dialogues.speaker: OLLIE
dialogues.text: Shadows. Things in the mist. (off David's look) i'm not drunk. I've been trying, believe me. Wish I could. 1 thought my eyes were playing tricks, but Dan saw it too. dialogues.speaker: OLLIE
dialogues.text: That woman is nuts, but she may be right about one thing...I think those things out there get more active when it gets dark. (checks his watch) Daylight's just about gone. dialogues.text: People come crowding. dialogues.text: Oh, God...
